questions.question: What she said made me angry.
questions.description: Here what she said is the subject of the verb made hence, it is a noun clause.

questions.question: I donâ€™t know what I am supposed to do.
questions.description: Here what I am supposed to do is the object of the verb know hence, it is a noun clause.

questions.question: I know a man who deals in antique furniture.
questions.description: Here who deals in antique furniture modifies the noun man hence, it is an adjective clause.

questions.question: She asked me what I was doing there.
questions.description: Here what I was doing there is the direct object of the verb asked hence, it is a noun clause.

questions.question: I love him because he is my brother.
questions.description: Because he is my brother is an adverb clause of reason.

questions.question: As soon as the bus arrived, the children rushed to board it.
questions.description: As soon as the bus arrived is an adverb clause of reason.

questions.question: Though I had a headache, I enjoyed the movie.
questions.description: Though I had a headache is an adverb clause of concession or contrast.

questions.question: How they escaped is a mystery.
questions.description: How they escaped is the subject of the verb is hence, it is a noun clause.

questions.question: All that I have is yours.
questions.description: That I have modifies the pronoun all hence, it is an adjective clause.

questions.question: She married an engineer whom she met on a bus.
questions.description: Whom she met on a bus is an adjective clause modifying the noun engineer.

questions.question: All that glitters is not gold.
questions.description: That glitters is an adjective clause modifying all.
